revision.text:
[[Image:Presentacion X Jornada Cultura Judia Caceres.jpg|thumb|250px|Carmen Heras, mayor of the city of [[Cáceres, Spain|Cáceres]] and the city council member for Tourism affairs, Francisco Torres, during the presentation of the European Day of Jewish Culture in 2009.]] The '''European Day of Jewish Culture''' is an event celebrated in several countries in [[Europe]].<ref>[http://www.eladelantado.com/noticia/local/86650/Segovia-se-suma-a-la-celebraci%C3%B3n-del-D%C3%ADa-Europeo-de-la-Cultura-Jud%C3%ADa Segovia se suma a la celebración del Día Europeo de la Cultura Judía]. "El Adelantado" Daily Newspaper</ref> The aim of this day is to organize activities related to Jewish culture and expose them to the public, with the intention that it would reveal the cultural and historical heritage of the Jewish people.<ref>[http://www.eldiadecordoba.es/article/ocio/505584/la/jornada/la/cultura/judia/propone/viajes/lucena/y/toledo.html La Jornada de la Cultura Judía propone viajes a Lucena y Toledo]. "El Día de Córdoba" Daily Newspaper</ref> The activities are coordinated by the [[European Association for the Preservation and Promotion of Jewish Culture]] (AEPJ), the [[European Council of Jewish Communities]], [[B'nai B'rith|B'nai B'rith Europe]] and the [[Network of Jewish Quarters in Spain]]. The aim of this day is to promote and raise awareness of [[Jewish culture]] to the wider society in the countries where this event takes place,<ref>[http://www.salom.com.tr/news/detail/12901-Sesh-septembre-el-Diya-Evropeo-de-la-Kultura-Judiya.aspx Sesh septembre, el Diya Evropeo de la Kultura Judiya]. "Şalom" Newspaper</ref> in the belief that a greater awareness of the culture, tradition and life of the different communities living in the same country or city helps people to know the "other", and thus, strengthens communication and dialogue between cultures in the country.
==History== The annual event was initiated in 1996 by the [[B'nai Brith]] of [[Strasbourg]] in the [[France|French]] département [[Bas-Rhin]] together with the local Agency for development of tourism.<ref>[http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2378 European Day of Jewish Culture 2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927220247/http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2378 |date=2011-09-27 }}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110922203129/http://www.ejpress.org/article/news/38750 European Jewish Press]</ref> It now involves twenty-seven European countries including [[Turkey]] and [[Ukraine]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110726202855/http://www.jewisheritage.org/jh/edjc.php?lang=1&e= jewishheritage.org]</ref> The original aim of the day was to permit access to, and ultimately restore, long abandoned [[synagogue]]s of architectural value like those of [[Wolfisheim]], [[Westhoffen]], [[Pfaffenhoffen]], [[Struth]], [[Diemeringen]], [[Ingwiller]] or [[Mackenheim]]. In 2000, a partnership was created between [[B'nai B'rith]] and the other organizations that currently participate in organizing the day's events.
==Activities== On this day exhibitions, concerts, panel discussions, lectures and excursions are organized in many [[Europe]]an countries. Topics such as [[Jewish Quarter (diaspora)|Jewish neighborhoods]], the coexistence of cultures, exhibitions on sculpture, painting, print, music and Jewish religious objects are discussed.
==Celebration Days==
* 1999: September 5 * 2000: September 6 * 2001: September 6 - "Judaism and the Arts" <ref>[http://www.jewisheritage.org/jh/edjc.php European Day of Jewish Culture: Themes]</ref> * 2002: September 6 - "Jewish Calendar and celebrations in Art, Music and Gastronomy" * 2003: September 6 - "Pesach" * 2004: September 6 - "Judaism and Education" * 2005: September 6 - "The Heritage of Jewish Cooking" * 2006: September 6 - "The European Routes of Jewish Heritage" * 2007: September 8 - "Testimonials" * 2008: September 4 - "Jewish Music" * 2009: September 6 - "Jewish Celebrations and Traditions" * 2010: September 5–15 - "Art in Judaism" * 2014: September 14 - "Women in Judaism" * 2015: September 6 - "Bridges" * 2016: September 4 - "Jewish languages" * 2017: September 3 - "Diaspora"
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Jewish culture]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Cafe (disambiguation)]] (link changed to [[Coffeehouse]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
[[File:Greek restaurant.JPG|thumb|An example of evening economic activity - a restaurant in [[Greece]].]] [[File:Staroměstské náměstí vánoce 08.jpg|thumb|[[Prague]] has a strong evening economy. Shown here are the Christmas markets after dark.]]
In [[urban planning|planning]], the '''evening economy''' describes [[economic activity]] taking place in the [[evening]] after many people finish daytime employment or formal education,<ref>http://www.gloucester.gov.uk/Website/Markets/Markets-information/EveningEconomyGroup.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.wolverhampton.gov.uk/environment/planning/policy/area_plans/evening_economy.htm</ref> such as eating and drinking, entertainment, and [[nightlife]] (which may be described by the related term '''nighttime economy''').
==Activities== The evening economy includes, but is not limited to: *Eating out - [[restaurant]]s, [[Coffeehouse|cafe]]s, [[takeaway]]s *Drinking - [[pub]]s and bars *Culture and entertainment - theatres, cinemas, [[live music]] and [[live comedy|comedy]] events, [[ten pin bowling]], [[ice skating]] *Sport - spectator sports including [[association football|football]], [[rugby football|rugby]] and [[greyhound racing]] often take place in the evening, especially during Mondays to Fridays. *Healthcare, police and firefighting
==Benefits and drawbacks== The benefits of a significant evening economy can include: *[[Recreation]] for people, which is often welcome after finishing work for the day *Increased [[employment]] due to local spending *Reduced [[social exclusion]] and increased vitality in towns
The drawbacks can include: *[[Noise pollution]] *[[Crime]] and/or [[anti-social behaviour]], particularly where [[alcohol]] is involved *[[Traffic congestion]]
==Regeneration== Evening economic activity has been used to drive [[urban regeneration]] in cities such as [[Manchester]], [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] and [[Dublin]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Economies]] [[Category:Nightlife]]

{{advert|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox Organization | name = Global Landscapes Forum | image = Global Landscapes Forum Logo, 2017.png | size = 200px | Caption = Logo | abbreviation = GLF | formation = {{Start date and age|2013|11|05|df=yes|p=y}} | extinction = | type = [[Non-profit organisation]] | status = | purpose = | headquarters = [[Bonn]], [[Germany]], [[Indonesia]] | location =[[Bonn]], [[Germany]] | region_served = Worldwide | membership = | language = | leader_title =Director General | leader_name =Robert Nasi | leader_title2 =Executive Producer | leader_name2 =John Colmey | parent_organization = [[Center for International Forestry Research]] | affiliations = [[World Bank]], [[United Nations Environment Programme]], German [[Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety]] (BMUB), German [[Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development]] (BMZ) | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | budget = | website = http://www.globallandscapesforum.org/ | remarks = |motto=Connect, share, learn and act.|formerly=[[Forest Day]], [[Agriculture and Rural Development Day]]}}
The '''Global Landscapes Forum''' ('''GLF''') is a knowledge-led multi-stakeholder forum dedicated to promoting the [[Integrated landscape management|landscape approach]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://peoplefoodandnature.org/blog/recognizing-common-ground-finding-meaning-in-integrated-landscape-management/ |title=Recognizing Common Ground: Finding Meaning in Integrated Landscape Management |last1=Friedman |first1=Rachel |last2=Shames |first2=Seth |last3=Sherr |first3=Sara |date=November 13, 2013 |website=EcoAgriculture Partners |access-date=September 13, 2017}}</ref>
== Overview == The GLF is the largest knowledge-led platform on sustainable land use. Since 2013, over 3,900 organizations and 150,000 people have taken part in Forum events in person and online. <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.globallandscapesforum.org/about/what-is-glf|title=What is the Global Landscapes Forum? - Global Landscapes Forum|work=Global Landscapes Forum|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en-US}}</ref> It is led by the [[Center for International Forestry Research]] (CIFOR).
== History == The inaugural GLF event took place alongside to [[2013 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP 19) in [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2013/11/17/1256032/-Warsaw-Global-Landscape-Forum-Lanches-Alongside-COP19 |title=Warsaw: Global Landscape Forum Launches Alongside COP19 |last=Phelan |first=Deborah |date=November 17, 2013 |website=[[Daily Kos]] |access-date=September 13, 2017}}</ref> It heralded the merger of [[International Day of Forests|Forest Day]] and [[Agriculture and Rural Development Day]], reflecting a scientific climate that favored breaking down research silos and utilizing an integrated landscape approach.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://forestsnews.cifor.org/11958/forest-day-time-to-move-on|title=Forest Day – time to move on|date=2012-12-02|work=CIFOR Forests News|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref> The first four major GLF events were held annually on the sidelines of the [[United Nations Climate Change conference|United Nations Climate Change Conference]].
Following a major funding injection from the German government, the GLF moved to establish a [[Secretariat (administrative office)|secretariat]] in [[Bonn]], Germany.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://archive.globallandscapesforum.org/glf-marrakesh/pressroom/cop22-german-government-supports-establishment-global-landscapes-forum-bonn/|title=COP22: German government supports establishment of Global Landscapes Forum in Bonn - 2016 Global Landscapes Forum: Marrakesh|work=2016 Global Landscapes Forum: Marrakesh|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref> This is part of an effort on the part of the German government and the city of Bonn to establish a "sustainability cluster" in the city.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bonn-international.org/international-profile/sustainability-cluster.html|title=Sustainability cluster - Bonn International|website=www.bonn-international.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref>
== Partners ==
CIFOR serves as the implementing organization of the GLF, and the current coordinating partners are the [[World Bank]], and the [[United Nations Environment Programme]].
As of 2017, the host country partners are the German [[Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety]] (BMUB) and [[Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development]] (BMZ).<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.cifor.org/corporate-news/german-government-pledges-commitment-global-landscapes-forum-promote-research-connect-results-communities-ground/|title=German Government supports establishment of Global Landscapes Forum in Bonn|work=Center for International Forestry Research|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Events ==
=== Predecessor Events === Following a move towards more integrated landscape approaches in both the [[forestry]] and [[agriculture]] sides of the research for [[Development aid|development]] sphere, the Global Landscapes Forum was born out of a merger of [[Global Landscapes Forum#Forest Day|Forest Day]] and [[Global Landscapes Forum#Agriculture and Rural Development Day (ARDD)|Agriculture and Rural Development Day]] (ARDD), both of which were formerly long-standing side events at the [[United Nations Climate Change conference]] (COP).
==== Forest Day ==== {{Main|International Day of Forests}} Forest Day was an annual COP side event co-organized by CIFOR and the [[Collaborative Partnership on Forests]], since the [[2007 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP13) in [[Bali]], [[Indonesia]].<ref name=":0" />
As of 2012, by resolution of the [[United Nations General Assembly]] on November 28, 2012, Forest Day became the [[International Day of Forests]].<ref name=declaration>[http://www.fao.org/forestry/36014-063ec88fa19cab1dfe473d7813290b32.pdf "International Day of Forests,"] United Nations General Assembly, November 28, 2012.</ref> Thus the sixth and final Forest Day was held on the sidelines of the [[2012 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP18) in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]].
====Agriculture and Rural Development Day ==== {{Main|Agriculture and Rural Development Day}} Agriculture and Rural Development Day (ARDD) was an annual COP side event. The first event took place as a side event at the [[2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP15) in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.agricultureday.org/ARDDay2009/|title=Agriculture and Rural Development Day 2009 Website|website=www.agricultureday.org|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref>
The fifth and final ARDD, called Agriculture, Landscapes, and Livelihoods Day 5 (ALL-5), took place alongside Forest Day on the sidelines of the COP18.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wle.cgiar.org/thrive/2012/12/05/story-agriculture-and-climate-change-road-we%E2%80%99ve-travelled|title=The Story of Agriculture and Climate Change: The Road We’ve Travelled|date=2012-12-05|work=Water, Land and Ecosystems|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en}}</ref>
=== Annual Events === The first major GLF event took place in [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]] during the [[2013 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP19).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://forestsnews.cifor.org/19350/a-sustainable-development-goal-on-landscapes-setting-the-agenda-at-cop19-in-warsaw|title=A Sustainable Development Goal on Landscapes: Setting the agenda at COP19 in Warsaw|date=2013-10-04|work=CIFOR Forests News|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
{{Quote box | quote = "We do not need to choose between fighting poverty and fighting climate change." | author = [[Felipe Calderon]], Former President of [[Mexico]] at the GLF in 2014<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/forest-trends/from-copenhagen-to-lima-a_b_6337650.html|title=From Copenhagen to Lima: An Observer’s Take on Why the Lima Call to Action Matters|work=The Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref> | source = | width = | align = right }}
The second major GLF event was held alongside the [[2014 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP20) from December 6–7, 2014. There were 1700 attendees and 95 organizations in attendance.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.globallandscapesforum.org/publication/2014-global-landscapes-forum-final-report/|title=2014 Global Landscapes Forum Final Report - Global Landscapes Forum|work=Global Landscapes Forum|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
This event saw the launch of the Youth in Landscapes initiative.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/rainforest-activist-found-murdered-in-ecuador-1.2030175|title=Rainforest activist found murdered in Ecuador|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
The third major GLF event was held alongside the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP21), December 5–6, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2015/12/02/hot-button-issues-climate-talks/ |title=Hot-Button Issues In The Climate Talks |last=Cadman |first=Timothy |date=December 2, 2015 |website=Clean Technica |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://germanwatch.org/en/11464|title=On the Sidelines of COP21 - The Global Landscapes Forum {{!}} Germanwatch e.V.|website=germanwatch.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref> There were 3200 attendees from 135 countries, including 19 Ministers and Heads of State, and 148 organizations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://archive.globallandscapesforum.org/publication/2015-global-landscapes-forum-outcome-statement/|title=Outcome Statement of the 2015 Global Landscapes Forum - Global Landscapes Forum|work=Global Landscapes Forum|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Notably, 200 indigenous peoples’ representatives were sponsored to attend the 2015 Forum, and 45% of those in attendance were female.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://archive.globallandscapesforum.org/publication/2015-global-landscapes-forum-donor-partner-report/|title=2015 Global Landscapes Forum Donor and Partner Report - Global Landscapes Forum|work=Global Landscapes Forum|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
Initiatives launched at this event include: *[[AFR100]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2015/12/05/at-climate-talks-african-nations-pledge-to-restore-forests?offset=50 |title=At UN climate talks African nations pledge to restore forests in fight against climate change |last=Chutel |first=Lynsey |date=December 6, 2015 |website=U.S. News |access-date=September 14, 2017}}</ref> *Blue Carbon Initiative<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.globallandscapesforum.org/17673/australia-indonesia-costa-rica-establish-international-partnership-blue-carbon-2015-global-landscapes-forum/|title=Australia, Indonesia and Costa Rica establish International Partnership for Blue Carbon at 2015 Global Landscapes Forum - Landscapes News|date=2015-12-11|work=Landscapes News|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}}</ref> *Indonesian National Carbon Accounting System (INCAS)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2015/12/07/indonesia-introduces-carbon-emissions-monitoring-system.html|title=Indonesia introduces carbon emissions monitoring system|last=Post|first=The Jakarta|work=The Jakarta Post|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en}}</ref> *Belantara Foundation *[[Danone]]'s New Climate Policy<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://downtoearth.danone.com/2015/11/11/danone-commits-to-ambitious-new-climate-policy/|title=Danone commits to ambitious new climate policy|work=Down To Earth|access-date=2017-12-16|language=fr-fr}}</ref>
The fourth major GLF event was held alongside the [[2016 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP22), November 16, 2016. During this event, the German [[Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety]] (BMUB) and [[Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development]] (BMZ) announced a major injection of core funding to support the development of the GLF for the next five years.<ref name=":1" />
Initiatives launched at this event include:<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://sdg.iisd.org/news/global-landscapes-forum-features-climate-and-forest-initiatives/|title=Global Landscapes Forum Features Climate and Forest Initiatives {{!}} News {{!}} SDG Knowledge Hub {{!}} IISD|last=Hub|first=IISD's SDG Knowledge|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}}</ref> * Climate Resilience through Sweetpotato (CReSP)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2016-11/ipc-crt111516.php|title=Climate Resilience through Sweetpotato (CReSP) announced|website=EurekAlert!|language=en|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref> * Tropical Forest Alliance 2020 (TFA 2020) African Palm Oil Initiative(APOI)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.mongabay.com/2016/11/seven-african-countries-pledge-to-protect-their-tropical-forests-from-unsustainable-oil-palm-development/|title=Seven African countries pledge to protect their tropical forests from unsustainable oil palm development|website=news.mongabay.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-16}}</ref> * Global Peatlands Initiative<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/blog/2016/11/new-un-initiative-aims-to-save-lives-and-cut-climate-change-by-protecting-peatlands/|title=New UN initiative aims to save lives and cut climate change by protecting peatlands - United Nations Sustainable Development|date=2016-11-17|work=United Nations Sustainable Development|access-date=2017-12-16|language=en-US}}</ref> * Earth Innovation Institute Produce and Protect Platform<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://earthinnovation.org/2016/11/earth-innovation-institute-launches-the-produce-and-protect-platform/|title=Earth Innovation Institute launches the Produce and Protect Platform {{!}} Earth Innovation Institute|website=earthinnovation.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref> * Five Great Forests Initiative<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://archive.globallandscapesforum.org/glf-marrakesh/launchpad/wednesday-16-november/5-great-forests-initiative/|title=The Five Great Forests Initiative - 2016 Global Landscapes Forum: Marrakesh|work=2016 Global Landscapes Forum: Marrakesh|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}}</ref> * Atlas of Deforestation and Industrial Plantations in Borneo<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://foreststreesagroforestry.org/for-a-better-borneo-new-map-reveals-how-much-terrain-has-changed/|title=For a better Borneo, new map reveals how much terrain has changed - Forests, Trees and Agroforestry|date=2017-02-16|work=Forests, Trees and Agroforestry|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
Following the major injection of funding from the German government during the [[Global Landscapes Forum#Marrakesh 2016: Climate Action for Sustainable Development|Marrakesh event]], the GLF moved to establish a more permanent presence in Bonn, Germany. While the [[2017 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] (COP23) was held in Bonn the same year from November 6–17, 2017, the Global Landscapes Forum event took place just over a month later on December 19–20, 2017. This marked the first year that the GLF existed as its own entity and not as a COP side event. For the first time, the [[Wangari Maathai#Wangari Maathai Forest Champion Award|Wangari Maathai Forest Champion Award]] was presented at the GLF.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cpfweb.org/93397/en/|title=Collaborative Partnership on Forests|last=Nations|first=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United|website=www.cpfweb.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref>
=== Thematic Events === The first Investment Case event took place on June 10–11, 2015 at the [[Royal Society]] in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]. It was an invitation-only symposium with 220 attendees from the finance sector.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.globallandscapesforum.org/publication/london-final-report/|title=Global Landscapes Forum: The Investment Case — Final Report - Global Landscapes Forum|work=Global Landscapes Forum|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}}</ref> It was coordinated by the [[European Investment Bank]], UN Environment, the World Bank, and the [[Program on Forests]] (PROFOR). Sessions were hosted by the [[OECD|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD), [[United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification]] (UNCCD), [[Unilever]], and the [[Climate Bonds Initiative]].<ref name=":2" />
The roadmap from this event were presented at a land use side event [[World Forestry Congress#14th World Forestry Congress: Durban, South Africa, 2015|14th World Forestry Congress]] (WFC XIV) in [[Durban]], [[South Africa]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cifor.org/wfc-2015/session/wednesday/toward-roadmap-sustainable-landscape-investments-at-scale/|title=Toward a roadmap for sustainable landscape investments at scale: Inputs from forestry science|work=Center for International Forestry Research|access-date=2017-12-17|language=en-US}}</ref> the theme of which was ''Forests and People: Investing in a Sustainable Future''.
Other key outcomes were presented to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) Standing Committee on Finance (SCF) workplan for 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ecoagriculture.org/event/global-landscapes-forum-the-investment-case/|title=EcoAgriculture Partners {{!}} Global Landscapes Forum: The Investment Case|website=ecoagriculture.org|language=en|access-date=2017-12-17}}</ref>
=== National and Policy Dialogues === Riau, Indonesia 2017: Laws and Best Practices for Reducing Fire and Haze
The [[AFR100]] initiative was launched at the GLF in Paris, 2015, and is also supported by the German government. Thus the GLF supported the Second Annual Partnership Conference in 2017, which brought together 23 partner countries, restoration champions, and technical partners such as the [[Food and Agriculture Organization|Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations]] (FAO), [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|International Union for the Conservation of Nature]] (IUCN), [[New Partnership for Africa's Development|New Partnership for Africa’s Development]] (NEPAD Agency), and [[World Vision International|World Vision]].
Organized with CIFOR, this policy dialogue workshop looked at gender-responsive [[Forest restoration#Forest landscape restoration|Forest and Landscape Restoration]].
== Controversies ==

The '''Halbert L. Dunn Award''' is the most prestigious award presented by the [[National Association for Public Health Statistics and Information Systems]] (NAPHSIS). The award has been presented since 1981 providing national recognition of outstanding and lasting contributions to the field of vital and health statistics at the national, state, or local level. <ref> {{cite web|url=https://naphsis-web.sharepoint.com/about/Pages/hldaward.aspx|title=Halbert L. Dunn Award|publisher=NAPHSIS|accessdate=8 November 2016}} </ref>
The award was established in honor of the late [[Halbert L. Dunn]], M.D., Director of the National Office of Vital Statistics from 1936 to 1960. Dr. Dunn was highly instrumental in encouraging the states to establish state vital statistics associations and played a major role in developing NAPHSIS. The award is presented at the Hal Dunn Awards Luncheon during the association’s annual meeting.
The winners of the Halbert L. Dunn Award have been:
Source: [https://naphsis-web.sharepoint.com/about/Pages/hldaward.aspx NAPHSIS]
*1981 Deane Huxtable *1982 Loren Chancellor *1983 Vito Logrillo *1984 Carl Erhardt *1985 Irvin Franzen *1986 W. D. "Don" Carroll *1987 Margaret Shackelford *1988 John Brockert, State Registrar, Utah *1989 Margaret Watts *1990 John Patterson *1991 Patricia Potrzebowski, State Registrar, Pennsylvania *1992 Rose Trasatti, National Association for Public Health Statistics and Information Systems (NAPHSIS) *1993 Garland Land, State Registrar, Missouri *1994 George Van Amburg *1995 Jack Smith *1996 ''no award'' *1997 Ray Nashold *1998 Iwao Moriyama *1999 ''no award'' *2000 George Gay *2001 Dorothy Harshbarger, State Registrar, Alabama *2002 Lorne Phillips, State Registrar, Kansas *2003 Mary Anne Freedman, Director of the Division of Vital Statistics, NCHS *2004 ''no award'' *2005 Joe Carney *2006 Dan Friedman *2007 Harry Rosenberg, National Center for Health Statistics *2008 [[Alvin T. Onaka]], Registrar, Hawaii *2009 Marshall Evans, National Center for Health Statistics *2010 Steven Schwartz, Registrar, New York City *2011 Charles Rothwell, Director, National Center for Health Statistics *2012 ''no award'' *2013 Stephanie Ventura, Director of Reproductive Statistics Branch, National Center for Health Statistics *2014 Bruce Cohen, Director of Research, MA Department of Health *2015 Isabelle Horon, State Registrar, Maryland *2016 Rose Trasatti Heim *2017 Jennifer Woodward, State Registrar, Oregon
==References== {{reflist}}

{{About|the feudal legal concept|the Pournelle book|High Justice}} {{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=June 2007}} {{no footnotes|date=September 2008}} }} '''High, middle and low justices''' are notions dating from Western [[feudalism]] to indicate descending degrees of judiciary power to administer justice by the maximal punishment the holders could inflict upon their subjects and other dependents.
Low justice regards the level of day-to-day civil actions, including voluntary justice, minor pleas, and petty offences generally settled by fines or light corporal punishment. It was held by many petty authorities, including many [[Lord of the manor|lords of the manor]], who sat in justice over the [[serf]]s, unfree tenants, and freeholders on their land. Middle justice would involve full civil and criminal jurisdiction, except for capital crimes, and notably excluding the right to pass the [[death penalty]], [[torture]] and severe [[corporal punishment]], which was reserved to authorities holding high justice, or the ''ius gladii'' ("right of the sword").
==Pyramid of feudal justice== Although the terms ''high'' and ''low'' suggest a strict subordination, this was not quite the case; a case could often be brought in any of several courts, with the principle of "prevention" (in the etymological sense of Latin ''praevenire'', "to come before") granting [[jurisdiction]] to the court in which the case was first filed or otherwise brought.
As a rule, each court administered justice in general (criminal cases were generally not separate from civil actions and other types of justice, while certain matters were separated such as [[Canon law (Catholic Church)|canon law]]), as long as the matter was not reserved for a higher court or by virtue of some ''[[privilegium fori]]'' (e.g., of clerics to be judged in canon courts by other clergy, sometimes under ecclesiastical law, the origin of the English [[Common law|common-law]] concept—[[benefit of clergy]]). In addition to civil and criminal trials, the notion of justice also included ''voluntary justice'', which is really the official recording of deeds (unilateral or bilateral) such as marital agreements, wills, grants, etc.
A right of appeal was not automatically available, only when explicitly established, and if so not always to a court of the superior political level and/or a higher degree of our trio. In fact, feudal justice was a labyrinth of specific customs and rules in nearly endless variation, not governed by any clear legal logic, and subject to significant historical evolution in time, though the largely [[customary law]] tended by nature to be quite conservative. In judicial matters—as in all spheres of life—feudal society did not see uniformity as either possible or necessarily desirable, each town and region having its own customs and ways of doing things, and resented attempts to interfere with them.
While the right of justice is held by many "unique" courts, relatively strong states make it a pillar of their absolutist (re)emergence to establish numerous courts to administer justice in their name in different territorial circumscriptions, such as the royal (high) sheriffs in England, and/or to impose an appeal (at least unifying the law as such) to a royal court, as to the various French provincial [[parlement]]s.
==High justice== {{see|Capital punishment in Germany}} [[File:Hand of justice Louvre MS85.jpg|thumb|150px|Hand of justice displayed at the [[Louvre]], Paris]] High justice, also known as ''ius gladii'' ("right of the sword") or in German as ''Blutgerichtsbarkeit'', ''Blutgericht'' (lit. "blood justice", "blood-court";<ref>"blood-court" is a literal of {{lang-de|Blutgericht}}; The ''Dictionary of the English and German Languages'' by Christoph Friedrich Grieb (1863) translates the term simply as "a criminal court".</ref> sometimes also ''Halsgericht'', lit. "neck-justice", or ''peinliches Gericht''<ref>[http://lexika.digitale-sammlungen.de/adelung/lemma/bsb00009132_3_0_452 Halsgericht] in [[Johann Christoph Adelung|Adelung]], ''Grammatisch-kritisches Wörterbuch der Hochdeutschen Mundart'' (1774–1786).</ref>) is the highest penal authority, including [[capital punishment]], as held by a sovereign—the [[sword of justice]] and hand of justice are [[regalia]] that symbolize it. In the early [[Holy Roman Empire]], high justice was reserved to the [[king of Germany|king]]. From the 13th century, it was transferred to the king's [[feudalism|vassals]] along with their fiefs. The first codification of capital punishment was the ''Halsgerichtsordnung'' passed by [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian I]] in 1499, followed in 1507 by the ''Constitutio Criminalis Bambergensis''. Both codes formed the basis of the ''Constitutio Criminalis Carolina'' (CCC), passed in 1532 under [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]]. In the [[Habsburg Monarchy]], all regional codes were superseded by the ''Constitutio Criminalis Theresiana'' in 1768.
The ''Blutbanner'' ("blood banner") or ''Blutfahne'' ("blood flag") was a solid red flag. It was presented to feudal lords as a symbol of their power of high jurisdiction (''Blutgerichtsbarkeit'') together with the heraldic banner of the fief. Some feudal houses adopted a red field symbolic of the blood banner into their coat of arms, the so-called ''Regalienfeld''. The [[Talschaft]] ([[forest canton]]) of [[canton of Schwyz|Schwyz]] used the blood banner as a [[war flag]] from ca. 1240, and was later incorporated into the [[flag of Schwyz]] and the [[flag of Switzerland]].
Often it is proudly displayed, in the form of relevant status symbols. Thus permanent [[gallows]] are often erected in prominent public places; the very word for them in French, ''potence'', is derived from the Latin "potentia" meaning "power".
High justice is held by all states and the highest vassals in the European type of feudal society, but may also be acquired by other authorities as part of a high degree of legal autonomy, such as certain cities; which in time often obtained other high privileges originally reserved for high nobility and sometimes high clergy. Other such privileges could include a seat in a [[diet (assembly)|diet]] or a similar feudal representative assembly, before the [[Estates of the realm|third estate]] as such even aspired to such "parliamentary" representation, or the right to [[mint (coin)|mint]] coins. These privileges indicating its so-called ''liberty'' was an "equal" enclave in the territorial jurisdiction of the neighboring feudal (temporal or ecclesiastical) Lord, sometimes even extending rather like a ''[[polis]]'' in Antiquity.
Not every [[Vogt]] held high justice. Up to the 18th century, for example, the blood court of much of what is now the [[canton of Zürich]] lay with [[County of Kyburg|Kyburg]], even in the territory ruled by the counts of [[Greifensee]]. The self-administration of the blood court was an important factor of [[Imperial immediacy]].
==See also== * [[Landgericht (medieval)]] * [[Private jurisdiction]] * [[Zwing und Bann]]
==References== {{Reflist}} *Richard J. Evans, ''Rituals of Retribution: Capital Punishment in Germany, 1600-1987'', Oxford University Press (1996).
{{DEFAULTSORT:High, Middle And Low Justice}} [[Category:Feudalism]] [[Category:Justice]] [[Category:Medieval law]] [[Category:Early Modern law]] [[Category:Legal history of the Holy Roman Empire]]

page.title: History of the Jews in Haiti

revision.text:
{{Jews and Judaism sidebar}}
The '''history of the Jews in Haiti''' is a rather long and complex one, as it stretches from the very beginning of the European settlement on the new island.
As of 2013, the Jewish population is around 25 predominately in [[Port-au-Prince]].<ref name="Jewish Virtual Library">{{cite web|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/haiti.html |title=Haiti |publisher=[[Jewish Virtual Library]] |accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref>
==History== ===The first Jewish settlement=== In 1492, the first [[Jews|Jew]] to ever set foot in Haiti was [[Luis de Torres]],<ref name="JTA">{{cite web|url=http://www.jta.org/2004/02/13/archive/around-the-jewish-world-as-haiti-burns-its-few-jews-choose-business-over-politics |title=Around the Jewish World As Haiti Burns, Its Few Jews Choose Business over Politics |editor=Press |date=13 February 2004 |publisher=JTA (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) |accessdate=21 December 2015}}</ref> an interpreter for [[Christopher Columbus]]. After Haiti was taken over and colonized by the French in 1633, many Dutch Jews (whom many were [[Marrano]]) emigrated from [[Brazil]] in 1634 and became employees of the French sugar plantations and further developed the trade. In 1683, the Jews were expelled from Haiti and all of the other French colonies, due to the [[Code Noir]] ''(Black Code)'', which not only restricted the activities of free Negroes, but forbade the exercise of any religion other than [[Roman Catholic]]ism (it included a provision that all slaves must be baptized and instructed in the Roman Catholic religion), and in turn ordered all the Jews out of France's colonies. However, despite the Black Code, a limited number of Jews remained in French trading companies as leading officials, including foreign citizens ([[Dutch people|Dutch]], [[Danish people|Danish]], or [[English people|English]]) or holders of special residence permits ''(lettres patentes)''. These Jews specialized in agricultural plantations. [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] Jews from [[Bordeaux]] and [[Bayonne]] settled mainly in the [[Tiburon Peninsula, Haiti|southern part]] of Haiti ([[Jacmel]], [[Jérémie]], [[Léogâne]], [[Les Cayes]], [[Petit-Goâve]], and [[Port-au-Prince]]) and Jews from [[Curaçao]] settled in the northern part ([[Cap-Haitien]], and [[Saint-Louis-du-Nord|Saint Louis]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0004_0_03964.html |title=Caribbeans, Spanish--Portuguese Nation of the: La Nacion |accessdate=17 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Arbell|first=Mordehay|title=The Jewish Nation of the Caribbean: The Spanish-Portuguese Jewish Settlements in the Caribbean and the Guianas|year=2002|publisher=Gefen Publishing House|isbn=965-229-279-6|pages=170, 292}}</ref>
However, in the mid-1700s, many Jews returned to Haiti and were later murdered or expelled during the slave revolt led by [[Toussaint Louverture]] in 1804, as many Jews also arrived from civil strife in Poland (with the invading Russia, Prussia and Austria).
Due to a lack of Sunday school and Jewish community centers, many youth did not grow up with a Jewish education and had to hide their Judaism because only Catholics were permitted to attend public school. Many Jews preferred to settle on the coastline, in port cities as many Jews were involved in commerce and trade establishing communities in major industry centers. Recently, archaeologists have uncovered an ancient synagogue of [[Crypto-Judaism|Crypto-Jews]] in the city of [[Jérémie]], the only one found on the island. Several Jewish tombstones have also been found in port cities such as [[Cap-Haïtien]] and [[Jacmel]].<ref name="JTA"/><ref name="Virtual Jewish World">{{cite web|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/haiti.html|title=The Virtual Jewish World: Haiti|publisher=|accessdate=19 October 2014}}</ref> Approximately 30 Jewish families by the end of the 19th century have arrived from [[Lebanon]], [[Syria]], and [[Egypt]]. A law in France was passed during this period that gave French citizenship to minorities in the Americas; thus many Jews from the Middle East felt secure emigrating to Haiti. These Jews in particular, brought with them their many [[Sephardi Jews|Sephardic]] customs and traditions.
==Modern Times== [[File:Haitian passport issued to Jewish holocaust survivor, stamped in Argentina July 1941.jpg|thumb|right|Passport issued to Hans Erich Max Emden by the Haitian government, who managed to escape the holocaust. In 1941 he used it to travel to Argentina.]] In 1915, during the [[United States occupation of Haiti]], roughly 200 Jews lived in Haiti at the time. During the 20 years period of occupation, many Jews left Haiti for the United States and [[South America]].<ref name="Virtual Jewish World"/> In 1937, Haiti was responsible for saving about 70 [[Jews|Jewish]] families (an estimated total of up to 300 lives) during the [[Holocaust]] (according to the [[American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee]]), by issuing passports and visas to Jews escaping [[Nazi]] persecution.<ref name="Virtual Jewish World"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jdc.org/jdc-field-blog/2010/from-the-archives-haiti.html |title=From the Archives: Haiti Helped Holocaust Refugees |editor=Press |date=28 January 2010 |publisher=American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee |accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> Some were [[Austria]]n Jews, [[Poland|Polish]] Jews, [[Germany|German]] Jews, and a trickle of [[Romania]]n Jew and [[Czech Republic|Czech]] Jewish descent. While these numbers are not as high as the number of Jewish families that [[Oskar Schindler]] helped save, a life is a life as Haiti played a small, yet critical role in saving Jewish lives during the darkest chapter in the Jewish story<ref name="Kreyollicious">{{cite web|url=http://kreyolicious.com/haiti-history-101-haitis-role-in-saving-jewish-families-during-the-holocaust/3976/ |title=Haiti History 101: Haiti’s Role in Saving Jewish Families During the Holocaust |author=KAT |accessdate=7 February 2014}}</ref> Unfortunately, though, it seems that more Jews were unable to acquire visas to Haiti due to the cost. Professor David Bankier, of the Institute of Contemporary Jewry at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, said that after 1938, ''“the cost [of a visa] was outrageous: If you wanted to go to Haiti, you had to pay $5,000.”''<ref name="Virtual Jewish World"/> Haiti at the time, was still unfairly paying reparations on an exorbitant debt with interest fees to France after the [[Haitian Revolution]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/08/16/france-asked-to-return-money-extorted-from-haiti/ |title=France Asked to Return Money ‘Extorted’ From Haiti |publisher=The New York Times |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref> that could have hindered their efforts to continue issuing these visas for free. There were others apart from this bunch who never came to Haiti at all, but from Germany they were given Haitian passports by the Haitian government that allowed them to flee Germany and into other countries.<ref name="Kreyollicious"/> Grateful to the Haitian government, many of these European Jews stayed in Haiti until the late 1950s in which many Haitian Jews left, so that their children could marry other Jews and not assimilate, while finding better economic opportunities. The 1957 Jewish population of Haiti was about 200.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Jewish Community of Haiti |url=https://dbs.bh.org.il/place/haiti |publisher=[[The Museum of the Jewish People at Beit Hatfutsot]] |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> The mid-20th century was a time where a continued departure of Jews from Haiti for the United States and Panama because of the economic conditions and civil violence in the country.<ref name="Jewish Virtual Library"/>
===Judaism===
Today, the Jewish community is led by Rabbi Douglas Lapin, a local businessman. The Jewish community is known as the "Consistoire d'Haiti" and has been recognized as the representative of the Jewish community by the Haitian Ministry of Religion (Ministere des Cultes) <Rep. d'Haiti; Ministere des Cultes DG/909 6 fevrier 2017>. Rabbi Lapin has likewise been recognized as the Rabbi in Haiti by the Haitian government<Tribunal de Premiere Instance de Port au Prince; Recipisse No. 3710084007-7; 4 Octobre 2017>. The community is very small and mostly consists of UN, NGO, and diplomatic personnel, although there are a small number of Haitian Jewish families. The community does Kosher chicken slaughtering (shkita) and has occasional gatherings for Jewish festivals such as Succos and Purim. There is also an Esrog, Myrtle (Hadasim) and Willow (Aravos) plantation to supply local needs for Succos. The community is working on developing a synagogue and community center. There is a complete library of Jewish liturgical books (seforim), Megillas Esther and Sefer Torah.
===Business===
The 1960s was a time of wealth and high hopes of large future development for Haiti. At the time met many family Jewish names such as: Alvarez, Cardozo, Cohen, Dreyfus, Goldman, Hakim, Hillel, Khan, Monsanto, Pereira, Salzmann, Silveira, and Weiner, which most had forgotten their ethno-religious backgrounds. Today, less than a hundred Jews remain in Haiti on its 9.5 million inhabitants; however, the Weiners (coffee exporters) and the Salzmanns (refugees from Austria) are still today relevant in trade.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thehaitianculture.blogspot.com/2013_05_01_archive.html |title=First Jews In Haiti |accessdate=2014-02-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.desinfos.com/spip.php?page=article&id_article=16680 |title=Haïti, les Juifs et Israël |editor=Yerouchalmi |date=17 January 2010 |publisher=Des Infos |accessdate=21 December 2015}} {{fr}}</ref>
==Notable Haitian Jews== * David Ades – political writer for [[Le Nouvelliste (Haiti)|Le Nouvelliste]] * Daniel Kedar – businessman; co-founder of Prodev * Elisabeth Silvera – President of the Fondation Haiti Solidarite (FHS) * [[Eric André]] – actor, comedian and television host * Gaston Michel – local tourism official * [[Gilbert Bigio]] – businessman billionaire of [[Syria]]n descent and Israeli honorary consul in Haiti * Kenneth Ades – financial service provider * [[Luis de Torres]] – one of the first Jews to settle on Haiti, and also [[Christopher Columbus]]'s interpreter * Monique Bigio – shareholder of [[PromoCapital]] * [[Monique Péan]] – fine [[jewelry designer]] * Reuven Bigio – founder of FAE (Fondation Appui à l'Education) * Robin Padberg – CEO of telecommunications company [[Comcel Haiti|Voila]] in Haiti * Rudolph Dana – CEO of Transec SA * [[Sol (musician)|Sol]] – is a musician of [[Russia]]n descent

[[File:Maltan knights castle in rh.jpg|thumb|right|400px|The [[Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes]] in the city of Rhodes, restored by the Italians in the 1930s]]
'''Italian colonists''' were settled in the '''Dodecanese Islands''' of the [[Aegean Sea]] in the 1930s by the [[Fascist]] [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Italian]] government of [[Benito Mussolini]], Italy having been in occupation of the Islands since the [[Italian-Turkish War]] of 1911.
By 1940, the number of Italians settled in the Dodecanese was almost 8,000, concentrated mainly in [[Rhodes]]. In 1947, after the [[World War II|Second World War]], the islands came into the possession of [[Kingdom of Greece|Greece]]: as a consequence most of the Italians were forced to emigrate and all of the Italian schools were closed. However, their architectural legacy is still evident, especially in Rhodes and [[Leros]].
==History== [[File:Hafenmarkt Rhodos02.jpg|thumb|left|View of the Market ("Nea Agora") of Mandraki, built during the Italian period.]]
The [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Kingdom of Italy]] occupied the [[Dodecanese]] Islands in the [[Aegean sea]] during the [[Italo-Turkish War|Italian-Turkish war]] of 1911. In the 1919 Venizelos-Tittoni Agreement, Italy promised to cede the overwhelmingly Greek-inhabited islands, except Rhodes, to [[Greece]], but this treaty was never implemented due to the Greek catastrophe in Asia Minor. With the [[Treaty of Lausanne]] in 1923, the Dodecanese was formally annexed by Italy, as the ''Possedimenti Italiani dell'Egeo''.
In the 1930s, Mussolini embarked on a program of [[Italianization]], hoping to make the island of Rhodes a modern transportation hub that would serve as a focal point for the spread of Italian culture in [[Greece]] and the [[Levant]]. The Fascist program did have some positive effects in its attempts to modernize the islands, resulting in the eradication of [[malaria]], the construction of hospitals, [[Aqueduct (water supply)|aqueducts]], a [[power plant]] to provide Rhodes' capital with [[electric lighting]] and the establishment of the Dodecanese [[Cadastre]].
The main castle of the Knights of St. John was also rebuilt. The concrete-dominated architectural style blended in with the islands' picturesque scenery (and also reminded the inhabitants of Italian rule), but has consequently been largely demolished or remodeled, apart from the famous example of the [[Leros]] town of Lakki (founded by the Italians as ''Portolago''), which remains a prime example of Italian [[Rationalism (architecture)|Rationalism]].
From 1923 to 1936, governor [[Mario Lago]] was able to integrate the Greek, [[Turkish people|Turkish]] and [[Judeo-Spanish|Ladino Jewish]] communities of the island of Rhodes with the Italian colonists. Lago's term of office constituted what might in retrospective be called the "Golden Period" of the Italian Dodecanese, with the economy booming and a relatively harmonious society.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dodecaneso.org/2336a.htm |title=Gli anni dorati 1923 - 1936 |publisher=Dodecaneso|language=it}}</ref>
[[File:Offices of the Prefecture of the Dodecanese 02.jpg|thumb|right|Former ''Palazzo Governale'']]
In the 1936 Italian census of the Dodecanese islands, the total population was 129,135, of which 7,015 were Italians. Nearly 80% of the Italian colonists lived in the island of [[Rhodes]]. Approximately 40,000 Italian soldiers and sailors were on military duty in the Dodecanese islands in 1940.
The appointment of Fascist [[Quadrumvirs|quadrumvir]] [[Cesare Maria De Vecchi]] as governor of the [[Italian Aegean Islands]] in 1936 marked a turning point. De Vecchi promoted a more vigorous and forceful program of Italianization, which was only interrupted by Italy's entry in World War II in 1940.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fJ3gVGqB1uQC&pg=PA436&lpg=PA436&dq=de+vecchi+dodecanese+italian+language&source=web&ots=gIgR81ZYv9&sig=2gIp1imYJUVYZH6iSY9gfq0KXck#PPA436,M1 |title=Rough Guide to the Dodecanese & East Aegean islands |first=Marc Stephen |last=Dubin |publisher=Rough Guides |year=2002 |isbn=978-1-85828-883-3 |page=436}}</ref>
Indeed, he promoted the possible unification of the islands to Italy as part of the fascist ideal of an [[Imperial Italy (fascist)|Imperial Italy]].
During [[World War II]], Italy joined the [[Axis Powers]], and used the Dodecanese as a naval staging area for its invasion of [[Crete]] in 1940. After the [[Armistice with Italy|surrender of Italy]] in September 1943, the islands briefly became a battleground between the [[Nazi Germany|Germans]], [[British Commonwealth|British]] and the Italians (the [[Dodecanese Campaign]]). The Germans prevailed, and although they were driven out of mainland Greece in 1944, the Dodecanese remained occupied until the end of the war in 1945, during which time nearly the entire Jewish population of 6,000 was [[the Holocaust|deported and killed]]. Only 1200 of these [[Judaeo-Spanish|Ladino]]-speaking Jews survived, thanks to their lucky escape to the nearby coast of Turkey with some help from the Italian colonists of Rhodes. In the [[Treaty of Peace with Italy, 1947|Treaty of Paris]] in 1947, the islands were ceded to Greece.
==Disappearance of the Italian community==
For the nearly 8,000 Italian colonists, after the Italian defeat in [[World War II]], started a process of return to Italy and successive disappearance. The Dodecanese officially passed from Italy to Greece in 1947, and in that year all the Italian schools were closed. Some of the Italian colonists remained in Rhodes and were quickly assimilated. Actually only a few dozen old colonists remain, but the influence of their legacy is evident in the relative diffusion of the [[Italian language]] mainly in [[Rhodes]] and Leros.
==Architectural legacy==
[[File:RodiScuolaMaschile17mm.JPG|thumb|left|Men's High School (Scuola Maschile)]]
The citadel of [[Rhodes, Greece|Rhodes city]] is a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]] thanks in great part to the large-scale restoration work carried out by the Italian authorities. The [[Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes]] formed the centerpiece of this project, after being largely destroyed by an ammunition explosion in 1856.
In the 1920s, the Italians demolished the houses that were built in and around the city walls during the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] period. They also turned the Jewish and Ottoman cemeteries into a green zone surrounding the Medieval Town. The Italians preserved what was left from the [[Knights Hospitaller|Knights]]' period, and destroyed all other Ottoman buildings that weren't of importance. Furthermore, in those years an "Institute for the study of the History and Culture of the Dodecanese region" was established, and major infrastructure work was done to modernize Rhodes. Buildings like the Aquarium were built, mainly in [[art deco]] style.
Indeed, in all the Dodecanese islands remains a huge architectural legacy<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dodecaneso.org/arch.htm |title=Architettura |publisher=Dodecaneso|language=it}}</ref> from the Italian colonists. Here are some examples: * The ''Grande Albergo delle Rose'' (now "Casino Rodos") built by [[Florestano Di Fausto]] and Michele Platania in 1927, with a mix of Arab, Byzantine and Venetian styles. * The ''Casa del Fascio'' of Rhodes, built in 1939 in typical fascist style. It serves now as the City Hall. * The ''Catholic church of San Giovanni'', built in 1925 by Rodolfo Petracco, as a reconstruction of the medieval cathedral church of the Knights of St. John. * The ''Teatro Puccini'' of the city of Rhodes, now called "National Theater", built in 1937 with 1,200 seats. * The ''Palazzo del Governatore'' in downtown Rhodes, built in 1927 in Venetian style. It now houses the offices of the Prefecture of the Dodecanese. * The ''Villaggio rurale San Benedetto'', now Kolymbia village, built in 1938 as a planned model village with all modern services. * The ''Community of Portolago'' (now Lakki) in the island of Leros, built in 1938 in typical Italian Deco style.

([[Trivandrum district]], [[Alappuzha district]]), Kerala
